.L JACKSON KIDD,'26

YES and NO

Former Students of English Make Gift
to University

Two grotesque blunders have betrayed our inexperience. We
perspiringly composed our first column without a thought of the
editorial blue-pencil! or the printer! Consequently, instead of
flipping a coin to locate its natural level, we find our yes-and-noness publicly committed to the stark and uncompromising ambiguity of big, black capitals. Privately, our cruelly jolted notions of beginner's luck have equally sworn us to a life-long
hatred of editorial license.
There also comes up the natural question of what-priceanonymity? We had naively counted on our far-flung obscurity
to carry us thru many embarrassing moments. We expected to
have a free rein, and to be guided only by whim and a sense of
irresponsibility. We were to be radical or reformer, Satanic or
soporific, at our own sweet will. Baldly, we were to get away with
a lot. We may yet. But it's all too plain that the editor and the
printer have usurped our two most cheerfully anticipated liberties: the right to be dull, and the right to be perplexed.

Circulation Manager
Associate Editors
A. RISLEY ENSOR, '26
CHARLES F. REESE, '27

HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, MD., MAY 1, 1925

THOSE “HIGH-HAT" COLLEGIANS
"Teach college men to wear overalls gracefully" is the advice of an article in a recent issue of the Christian Science Monitor.
The National Industrial Conference Board found this to
be the antidote necessary for the present failure of college-bred
men to take advantage of their training in the industrial world.
It was admitted that the college man did not "fit in". Investigation found that the college man was "high hatting" his
fellow workers. The reasons for this were: the scoffing attitude of the untrained laborers toward the "Collidge Boy"; and
the failure of the college man to "fraternize" with the great
unwashed.
Arthur C. Jewett, in charge of the investigation, lays much
of the blatn..t on the university graduate. "Sometimes if there
were less effort spent in making it known that the beginner is
a college graduate," he says,"and more in trying to conceal the
fact until it proves a practical advantage, as it eventually will,
there would be fewer disappointments."
Often, it was pointed out, the college man starts at a disadvantage. Instead of realizing this and striving to learn from
the older but less highly trained workers, he too often overrates his theoretical work. The result is a cleavage between the
experienced and the educated workers with a consequent loss of
efficiency.
College men must realize that the classroom is but the
prelude. The main work comes later. Sheepskins mean nothing until they have become begrimed with the soot of the factory.

Nevertheless, it is undeniable that weighty problems have
been solved. For this unexpected assistance we are grateful. In
fact, if this good samaritanism continues, we might ever remark
that it will solve the many problems of this column for once and
for all.
It is possible, of course, that ye editors found much that was
inexperienced and without promise. For instance, we entirely
neglected our preliminary bow to our editorial colleagues, in
general, and to their bosses in particular. We fear that it is now
too late for that pleasant gesture. We also fear that we are not
exactly in the mood for it. Out of a spirit of pure suite we feel
much more like printing a bit of damning evidence that we discovered recently in the Black and Blue Jay Office. imprimatur!
"Save Your Old Jokes. Don't forget.
Don't throw away your old copy—
Show your college spirit.
The NEWS-LETTER is glad to get it."
Aha! Such are the inner workings of Hopkins journalism!
Such is the inside dope on running a newspaper for college men!
In such a low and evil way does the NEWS-LETTER cater to the
Jay! Aha!
Heads I win and tails you lose. If the notice is genuine, so
much the worse. If it is Blue Jay wit and wisdom, the joke is
certainly on the NEWS-LETTER. At any rate, we shall attempt a
Sherlock Holmes on this question, or (pardon us, follow moderns)
a Craig Kennedy, with an eye to next week's column.
Last week, we expressed the fear that our contributors, if
any, would be prone to say that right thing at the wrong time.
Well . . . . we print without comment the following communication regarding two gentlemen who seem to be unexpected "fratres
in facultate."
Dear Yea-and-Nay:
Permit me a few animadversions upon Professorial grading.
When a certain Dr. —s hands out a six or a seven, he delights
in expatiating: "Original thought gets the ten. Don't learn your
stuff. Shoot first-class bull." That is admirably frank. Our
summaries of Hoemle's "Metaphysics" have been quite successfully original
No one would have thought that Ma Gr—n-- had any idea in
common with the fiery philosopher. Will you explain to impious,
impish and impertinent Comus how it happens that two reviews
of the same Browning play—one by a man who had read the play,
one by an artistic purveyor of bull—should have so fooled the
veteran marksman? .
Will Yea-and-Nay please tell me how these finger-twirlers
do it?
Yours for a while—

COMUS.
PUBLICITY SET TO MUSIC
The most recent appearance of the Blue Jay orchestra at
the Maryland Theatre has stirred up quite a bit of comment.
To those who feel that the fair and lofty name of Hopkins
has been degraded may we point out that the Blue Jays have
given Hopkins more publicity than half a dozen Publicity
Boards ever will. And they are but following the precedent of
many other college orchestras—among them the Pennsylvanians, Sleepy Hall's Yale Orchestra, the V. M. I. Keydets, and
the like.

TEA DANCE
A tea dance will be held in the
C. E. Hall tomorrow immediately following the lacrosse game.
The Blue Jay Orchestra will furnish the music.

•
INGE LECTURE

To the Jays may we suggest that their act would retain its
"home talent" atmosphere better if outsiders were strictly
barred. If the feminine touch is absolutely necessary there are
among our more or less decorative co-eds several who are naturally cast for a comedy number.

A portrait of Dr. Herbert E.
Greene, who recently retired as Collegiate Professor of English, is
rapidly nearing completion and will
be presented to the University at
the Commencement exercises. The
picture will hang in the library
along with those of other faculty
members.
The portrait is being painted by
Thomas Corner, a prominent local
artist. Mr. Cotner has done four
of the pictures now in the library,
notably the one of Ex-Dean Griffin. Dr. Greene's portrait, which is
nearly finished, is said to be a striking likeness. •
The presentation of the gift is
being made by a group of alumni
who have studied under Dr. Greene.
Prof. John C. French is chairman
of the committee in charge of the
arrangements.
HOPKINS "Y" SENDS MEN
TO CONFERENCE
May 1, 2, and 3 will witness the
Annual Interstate Y. M. C. A.
Training Conference, which will
be held at Sherwood Forest. Hopkins will send five delegates:
Harp, Marsh, Easton, Dalzelle
and Ensor.
The Conference will include the
Y. M. C. A.'s of Maryland, Delaware, and the District of Columbia. Students will have charge
of all affairs of the meeting, except for the opening and closing
addresses, for
which outside
speakers of reputation have been
obtained.
The topic of discussion which
is creating the most interest is,
"The Campus Situation and the
Place of the Y. M. C. A." Julian
Price, of the Johns Hopkins Medical School, will lead discussion in
the group, and will also take entire charge of all devotional studies.
The delegates will return Sunday night.

HULLABALOO OUTSOON
"The 1925 Hullabaloo will
appear on the campus a day
or two before the examinations begin," said James R.
Young, the Editor-in-Chief,
when interviewed yesterday.
"This is the earliest date for
the appearance of the year
book for some years."
The Hullabaloo will contain numerous features of an
unusual nature, according to
Young."It has been claimed
that all year books are stereotyped, of the same general
nature, that it is impossible
to vary from the usual form"
he said. "We have done our
best to make the 1925 Hullabaloo distinctive, and I can
assure the Senior Class that
this year's book varies
greatly from those of past
years.
"All printing work is completed and the binding and
one or two similar mechanical details remain unfinished;
the book is nearly complete."

Last week we listed Syracuse
and Princeton with Johns Hopkins and Navy, as the best college twleves. Now we must substitute Army for Syracuse, after
the 5-1 victory of the former over
the Orange; and we substitute
Hobart for Princeton. Last year
Syracuse was undefeated, although the Crescents, Toronto,
etc., were on her schedule. Apparently graduations did her no
good, or else Army is unusually
strong this year.

With the crucial Navy game
just eight days off, we note with
anxiety the slackness of the Hopkins attack. Turnbull and Almy
are in their stride, wasting few
opportunities; but Robinson and
Bates do not yet ring the bell on
every crease shot. Still, our
chances against Navy are good.
We have a big repertoire of plays,
strong reserves, a well-balanced
field, and two good goal-keepers.
The slogan, "Beat Navy", has
been sounding louder and louder

NEW VIEW OF DR. GOODNOW'S
NEW PLAN IS OFFERED BY "COMUS"
By Comus

Certain members of the student body have been asked, "What
do you think of the New Plan?" Eli Siegel came out to interview
Magill, and spent many minutes of metaphysical time persuading
Mac that studies are more interesting than football. (Mac remained
skeptical). The expressed opinion of the students was about divided
some approving and others condemning. One senior said, "I believe
there should be, in this country, an institution of the type suggested,
but I hate to see Hopkins drop its extra-curricular charms." The
undergraduate who devotes the usual one-half of one per cent, of
his time to meditation, believes that Dr. Goodnow's idea is excellent.
But this same undergrad is attached to the Blue Jay, or football, or
lacrosse, or it may even be a social frat, and he looks forward to the
time when a younger brother will throw new energy into the upbuilding of this favorite sideline. So now, when the New Plan
looms more definitely near at hand, it also looms more threateningly. Many who favored the plan are now backing down, avoiding it. Why? The answer we undergraduates give is the spirit
of the place will be changed. The spirit of the place!
When the spirit of the place is threatened, it wakes up, in
every man, a realization of the significance of its meaning. Those
huge Western Universities are morbid, or crude—raw in many
different ugly manners of rawness. Hopkins is riper, cleaner,
more substantial. It is sufficiently small to permit intimacy. We
have grown attached to it. And we do not want these places
overrun with bespectacled, nauseating transfers .from the crude
big Universities. We would be exclusive. We would save this
spirit for our younger friends.
This is part of the answer to the rude question, "What do you
think of the New Plan?"

Former Students of English Make Gift

Two grotesque blunders have betrayed our inexperience. We
perspiringly composed our first column without a thought of the
editorial blue-pencil! or the printer! Consequently, instead of
flipping a coin to locate its natural level, we find our yes-and-noness publicly committed to the stark and uncompromising ambiguity of big, black capitals. Privately, our cruelly jolted notions of beginner's luck have equally sworn us to a life-long
hatred of editorial license.
There also comes up the natural question of what-priceanonymity? We had naively counted on our far-flung obscurity
to carry us thru many embarrassing moments. We expected to
have a free rein, and to be guided only by whim and a sense of
irresponsibility. We were to be radical or reformer, Satanic or
soporific, at our own sweet will. Baldly, we were to get away with
a lot. We may yet. But it's all too plain that the editor and the
printer have usurped our two most cheerfully anticipated liberties: the right to be dull, and the right to be perplexed.

HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, MD., MAY 1, 1925

THOSE “HIGH-HAT" COLLEGIANS
"Teach college men to wear overalls gracefully" is the advice of an article in a recent issue of the Christian Science Monitor.
The National Industrial Conference Board found this to
be the antidote necessary for the present failure of college-bred
men to take advantage of their training in the industrial world.
It was admitted that the college man did not "fit in". Investigation found that the college man was "high hatting" his
fellow workers. The reasons for this were: the scoffing attitude of the untrained laborers toward the "Collidge Boy"; and
the failure of the college man to "fraternize" with the great
unwashed.
Arthur C. Jewett, in charge of the investigation, lays much
of the blatn..t on the university graduate. "Sometimes if there
were less effort spent in making it known that the beginner is
a college graduate," he says,"and more in trying to conceal the
fact until it proves a practical advantage, as it eventually will,
there would be fewer disappointments."
Often, it was pointed out, the college man starts at a disadvantage. Instead of realizing this and striving to learn from
the older but less highly trained workers, he too often overrates his theoretical work. The result is a cleavage between the
experienced and the educated workers with a consequent loss of
efficiency.
College men must realize that the classroom is but the
prelude. The main work comes later. Sheepskins mean nothing until they have become begrimed with the soot of the factory.

Nevertheless, it is undeniable that weighty problems have
been solved. For this unexpected assistance we are grateful. In
fact, if this good samaritanism continues, we might ever remark
that it will solve the many problems of this column for once and
for all.
It is possible, of course, that ye editors found much that was
inexperienced and without promise. For instance, we entirely
neglected our preliminary bow to our editorial colleagues, in
general, and to their bosses in particular. We fear that it is now
too late for that pleasant gesture. We also fear that we are not
exactly in the mood for it. Out of a spirit of pure suite we feel
much more like printing a bit of damning evidence that we discovered recently in the Black and Blue Jay Office. imprimatur!
"Save Your Old Jokes. Don't forget.
Don't throw away your old copy—
Show your college spirit.
The NEWS-LETTER is glad to get it."
Aha! Such are the inner workings of Hopkins journalism!
Such is the inside dope on running a newspaper for college men!
In such a low and evil way does the NEWS-LETTER cater to the
Jay! Aha!
Heads I win and tails you lose. If the notice is genuine, so
much the worse. If it is Blue Jay wit and wisdom, the joke is
certainly on the NEWS-LETTER. At any rate, we shall attempt a
Sherlock Holmes on this question, or (pardon us, follow moderns)
a Craig Kennedy, with an eye to next week's column.
Last week, we expressed the fear that our contributors, if
any, would be prone to say that right thing at the wrong time.
Well . . . . we print without comment the following communication regarding two gentlemen who seem to be unexpected "fratres
in facultate."
Dear Yea-and-Nay:
Permit me a few animadversions upon Professorial grading.
When a certain Dr. —s hands out a six or a seven, he delights
in expatiating: "Original thought gets the ten. Don't learn your
stuff. Shoot first-class bull." That is admirably frank. Our
summaries of Hoemle's "Metaphysics" have been quite successfully original
No one would have thought that Ma Gr—n-- had any idea in
common with the fiery philosopher. Will you explain to impious,
impish and impertinent Comus how it happens that two reviews
of the same Browning play—one by a man who had read the play,
one by an artistic purveyor of bull—should have so fooled the
veteran marksman? .
Will Yea-and-Nay please tell me how these finger-twirlers
do it?
Yours for a while—

COMUS.
PUBLICITY SET TO MUSIC
The most recent appearance of the Blue Jay orchestra at
the Maryland Theatre has stirred up quite a bit of comment.
To those who feel that the fair and lofty name of Hopkins
has been degraded may we point out that the Blue Jays have
given Hopkins more publicity than half a dozen Publicity
Boards ever will. And they are but following the precedent of
many other college orchestras—among them the Pennsylvanians, Sleepy Hall's Yale Orchestra, the V. M. I. Keydets, and
the like.

A portrait of Dr. Herbert E.
Greene, who recently retired as Collegiate Professor of English, is
rapidly nearing completion and will
be presented to the University at
the Commencement exercises. The
picture will hang in the library
along with those of other faculty
members.
The portrait is being painted by
Thomas Corner, a prominent local
artist. Mr. Cotner has done four
of the pictures now in the library,
notably the one of Ex-Dean Griffin. Dr. Greene's portrait, which is
nearly finished, is said to be a striking likeness. •
The presentation of the gift is
being made by a group of alumni
who have studied under Dr. Greene.
Prof. John C. French is chairman
of the committee in charge of the
arrangements.
HOPKINS "Y" SENDS MEN
TO CONFERENCE
May 1, 2, and 3 will witness the
Annual Interstate Y. M. C. A.
Training Conference, which will
be held at Sherwood Forest. Hopkins will send five delegates:
Harp, Marsh, Easton, Dalzelle
and Ensor.
The Conference will include the
Y. M. C. A.'s of Maryland, Delaware, and the District of Columbia. Students will have charge
of all affairs of the meeting, except for the opening and closing
addresses, for
which outside
speakers of reputation have been
obtained.
The topic of discussion which
is creating the most interest is,
"The Campus Situation and the
Place of the Y. M. C. A." Julian
Price, of the Johns Hopkins Medical School, will lead discussion in
the group, and will also take entire charge of all devotional studies.
The delegates will return Sunday night.

HULLABALOO OUTSOON
"The 1925 Hullabaloo will
appear on the campus a day
or two before the examinations begin," said James R.
Young, the Editor-in-Chief,
when interviewed yesterday.
"This is the earliest date for
the appearance of the year
book for some years."
The Hullabaloo will contain numerous features of an
unusual nature, according to
Young."It has been claimed
that all year books are stereotyped, of the same general
nature, that it is impossible
to vary from the usual form"
he said. "We have done our
best to make the 1925 Hullabaloo distinctive, and I can
assure the Senior Class that
this year's book varies
greatly from those of past
years.
"All printing work is completed and the binding and
one or two similar mechanical details remain unfinished;
the book is nearly complete."

Hobart for Princeton. Last year
Syracuse was undefeated, although the Crescents, Toronto,
etc., were on her schedule. Apparently graduations did her no
good, or else Army is unusually
strong this year.

With the crucial Navy game
just eight days off, we note with

opportunities; but Robinson and
Bates do not yet ring the bell on

chances against Navy are good.
We have a big repertoire of plays,

field, and two good goal-keepers.

NEW VIEW OF DR. GOODNOW'S
NEW PLAN IS OFFERED BY "COMUS"
By Comus

Certain members of the student body have been asked, "What
do you think of the New Plan?" Eli Siegel came out to interview
Magill, and spent many minutes of metaphysical time persuading
Mac that studies are more interesting than football. (Mac remained
skeptical). The expressed opinion of the students was about divided
some approving and others condemning. One senior said, "I believe
there should be, in this country, an institution of the type suggested,
but I hate to see Hopkins drop its extra-curricular charms." The
undergraduate who devotes the usual one-half of one per cent, of
his time to meditation, believes that Dr. Goodnow's idea is excellent.
But this same undergrad is attached to the Blue Jay, or football, or
lacrosse, or it may even be a social frat, and he looks forward to the
time when a younger brother will throw new energy into the upbuilding of this favorite sideline. So now, when the New Plan
looms more definitely near at hand, it also looms more threateningly. Many who favored the plan are now backing down, avoiding it. Why? The answer we undergraduates give is the spirit
of the place will be changed. The spirit of the place!
When the spirit of the place is threatened, it wakes up, in
every man, a realization of the significance of its meaning. Those
huge Western Universities are morbid, or crude—raw in many
different ugly manners of rawness. Hopkins is riper, cleaner,
more substantial. It is sufficiently small to permit intimacy. We
have grown attached to it. And we do not want these places
overrun with bespectacled, nauseating transfers .from the crude
big Universities. We would be exclusive. We would save this
spirit for our younger friends.
This is part of the answer to the rude question, "What do you
think of the New Plan?"
